elements.content: From the perspective of the chromophore, 1,1,2,2-tetrakis­(4-(pyridin-4-yl)­phenyl)­ethane (TPPE) with the π-electron-rich tetraphenylethylene (TPE) and aggregation induced emission feature is selected as functional ligand to construct the fluorescent metal–organic frameworks. Three luminescent MOFs (1–3) have been successfully synthesized. Through combining 4,4′,4″-nitrilotrisbenzoic acid (H3TNB) with electron-donor triphenylamine (TPA), the highly porous pillared-layer compound 1 [Zn3(TPPE)1/2(TNB)2]­(4DMA·7H2O) was synthesized; interestingly, this MOF sensor film realizes the fast detection for nitrobenzene compounds with a response time of less than 3 min as well as good recyclability. Compound 2 [Zn7(TPPE)2(SO4 2–)7]­(DMF·H2O) exhibits the clear “turn-off” quenching responses for Cr2O7 2– in aqueous phase with high selectivity and sensitivity. Meanwhile, the fluorescent properties of compound 3 [Zn2(TPPE)3/2(NO3 –)­(OH–)­(H2O)]­(DMF·2H2O) were also investigated. Thus, these MOF materials could serve as the promising platform for luminescent sensing.

Three luminescent MOFs (1-3) have been successfully synthesized. Through combining 4,4',4"-nitrilotrisbenzoic acid (H3TNB) with electron-donor triphenylamine (TPA), the highly porous pillared-layer compound 1 [Zn3(TPPE)1/2(TNB)2](4DMA⋅7H2O) was synthesized; interestingly, this MOF sensor film realizes the fast detection for nitrobenzene compounds with a response time of less than 3 min as well as good recyclability. Compound 2 [Zn7(TPPE)2(SO4 2-)7](DMF⋅H2O) exhibits the clear "turn-off" quenching responses for Cr2O7 2- in aqueous phase with high selectivity and sensitivity. Meanwhile, the fluorescent properties of compound 3 [Zn2(TPPE)3/2(NO3 -)(OH-)(H2O)](DMF⋅2H2O) were also investigated. Thus, these MOF materials could serve as the promising platform for luminescent sensing.

MOF sensor film of compound 1 realizes the fast vapor-phase detection for nitrobenzene compounds with a response time of less than 3 min as well as good recyclability. Compound 2 exhibits the clear “turn-off” quenching responses for Cr2O7 2− in aqueous phase with high selectivity and sensitivity.

elements.content: Nitroaromatic (NAC) explosives not only as hazardous substances pose threats to homeland security and society stability but also as pollutants have an impact on environmental protection; thus, rapid and sensitive detection of nitroaromatic (NAC) explosives has become one of the most pressing issues. It is known that chromium, as a toxic species, exists in the form of the highly soluble Cr­(VI) anions (such as HCrO4 –, CrO4 2–, or Cr2O7 2–) in many environmental conditions, so it is also important to monitor the concentration of chromate anions for ecologicalsystem and human health. Till now, among the various detection methods, fluorescence-based chemical sensors systems are gaining increasing attention for detection of high explosives and heavy metal ion substances, due to the high sensitivity, selectivity and simplicity, besides, with the smart to practical application in both liquid-phase detection as well as vapor-phase sensing.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Nitroaromatic (NAC) explosives not only as hazardous substances pose threats to homeland security and society stability but also as pollutants have an impact on environmental protection; thus, rapid and sensitive detection of nitroaromatic (NAC) explosives has become one of the most pressing issues. It is known that chromium, as a toxic species, exists in the form of the highly soluble Cr(VI) anions (such as HCrO4 -, CrO4 2-, or Cr2O7 2-) in many environmental conditions, so it is also important to monitor the concentration of chromate anions for ecologicalsystem and human health. Till now, among the various detection methods, fluorescence-based chemical sensors systems are gaining increasing attention for detection of high explosives and heavy metal ion substances, due to the high sensitivity, selectivity and simplicity, besides, with the smart to practical application in both liquid-phase detection as well as vapor-phase sensing.

elements.content: Metal–Organic Frameworks (MOFs), as a class of porous crystalline materials, featuring the high permanent porosity, host–guest interaction, diversity in structure and composition, display a variety of applications including gas storage, sensing, clean energy, etc. MOFs constructed from fluorescent functional ligands have received considerable attention, in particular because of their superiority in sensing applications. Luminescent MOFs (LMOFs) offer several advantages toward the sensing applications. The organic ligands in MOFs often consist of π-electron-rich aromatic moieties which can enhance fluorescence intensity, lifetime, and quantum efficiencies compared to ligand alone. In theory, MOFs can serve as excellent chemical sensors to detect trace amounts of nitroaromatic compounds, because fluorescence behaviors could be easily achieved by a photoinduced electron-transfer mechanism (from π-electron-rich MOFs to π-electron-deficient nitroaromatic compounds). Luminescent MOFs have been successfully exploited as a unique class of sensing platform in the detection of NACs. Nevertheless, MOFs with high porosity are usually sensitive to moisture and air, which limits the sensing application in vapor phase. Therefore, it is essential to exploit the air-resistant MOFs for the practical vapor-phase explosive detection. Meanwhile, it is also necessary to obtain the water-stable MOFs to improve the sensitivity of Cr­(VI) aqueous-phase detection.

elements.content: In recent years, aggregation-induced emission (AIE) fluorophores have sparked a rapid expansion in the domain of photoluminescent sensors and electroluminescent devices. Tetraphenylethylene as well-studied AIE fluorophores, which exhibit enhanced emission in the solid state, have been successfully utilized for chemo- and biosensing and fluorescence imaging. Some TPE-based MOFs have been synthesized and acted as a platform for sensitive detection.

elements.content: TPPE ligand was synthesized via Suzuki reaction. All other reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction analysis has been determined on a D/Max-2500 X-ray diffractometer using Cu Ka (λ = 1.54 Å) radiation. Thermal stability studies were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermonuclear thermoanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under an air atmosphere. Element microanalyses were carried out with a PerkinElmer 240 elemental analyzer. Ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) adsorption spectra were recorded at room temperature on a PerkinElmer Lambda 35 spectrophotometer. The luminescent sensing measurements were performed on a Hitachi F-7000 Fluorescence spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
General Information

Materials and Instrumentation

TPPE ligand was synthesized via Suzuki reaction. All other reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction analysis has been determined on a D/Max-2500 X-ray diffractometer using Cu Ka (λ = 1.54 Å) radiation. Thermal stability studies were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermonuclear thermoanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under an air atmosphere. Element microanalyses were carried out with a PerkinElmer 240 elemental analyzer. Ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) adsorption spectra were recorded at room temperature on a PerkinElmer Lambda 35 spectrophotometer. The luminescent sensing measurements were performed on a Hitachi F-7000 Fluorescence spectrophotometer.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.056 g, 0.20 mmol), H3TNB (0.015 g, 0.042 mmol), and TPPE (0.010 g, 0.014 mmol) was added in a 25 mL glass vial; subsequently, 5 mL of dimethylacetamide (DMA) solvent was added to the solids. The vial was heated in a programmable oven at 373 K for 24 h, and a light yellow-green crystalline solid was obtained. The obtained yield: 81.4% (based on TPPE). Anal. Calcd for C81H74­N8O15Zn3: C, 58.55; H, 4.46; N, 6.75; Found: C, 59.66; H, 4.48; N, 6.24%.

elements.content: ZnSO4·7H2O (0.056 g, 0.20 mmol) and TPPE (0.010 g, 0.014 mmol) were mixed in a 25 mL glass vial; subsequently, 9 mL of solvent (DMF/i-PrOH/DMSO, 6:2:1 mL) was added, and another two drops of HBF4 were added by eyedropper. Then, the vial was heated in a programmable oven at 393 K for 96 h and cooled naturally. Further, the vials stayed still for 2 months, and a light yellow-green crystalline solid was obtained. The obtained yield: 10.2% (based on TPPE). Anal. Calcd for C92H75­N9O34­S7Zn7: C, 44.10; H, 2.92; N, 4.91; Found: C, 45.02; H, 2.98; N, 4.34%.

elements.content: Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.042 g, 0.15 mmol) and TPPE (0.010 g, 0.014 mmol) were mixed in a 25 mL glass vial; subsequently, 6 mL of solvent (DMF/MeOH/H2O, 4:1:1 mL) was added to the solids, and another three drops of HNO3 (2 mol/L) were added by eyedropper. elements.content: The diffraction data were measured at 100 or 120 K under nitrogen flowing on a Rigaku AFC10 diffractometer with a Rigaku Supranava X-ray generator with confocal monochromatic Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). All structures were solved by a direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares using SHELX-2014 and Olex2.0. The structure was solved with the XS structure solution program using direct methods and refined with the XL refinement package using Least Squares minimization. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal displacement coefficients. All hydrogen atoms were located on the geometrically ideal positions and refined using a riding model. The contribution of the missing solvent molecule and other ionic residues to the diffraction patterns was subtracted from the reflection data by the SQUEEZE method as implemented in PLATON. Crystallographic data have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (deposition numbers CCDC 1535823, 1557472, and 1557468 for 1-3). The data details of compound 1 are listed in Tables S1 and S2.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Diffraction Analysis

The diffraction data were measured at 100 or 120 K under nitrogen flowing on a Rigaku AFC10 diffractometer with a Rigaku Supranava X-ray generator with confocal monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). All structures were solved by a direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares using SHELX-2014 and Olex2.0. The structure was solved with the XS structure solution program using direct methods and refined with the XL refinement package using Least Squares minimization. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal displacement coefficients. All hydrogen atoms were located on the geometrically ideal positions and refined using a riding model. The contribution of the missing solvent molecule and other ionic residues to the diffraction patterns was subtracted from the reflection data by the SQUEEZE method as implemented in PLATON. Crystallographic data have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (deposition numbers CCDC 1535823, 1557472, and 1557468 for 1-3). The data details of compound 1 are listed in Tables S1 and S2.

elements.content: The luminescent properties were examined in the solid state, in organic solvent suspensions, and vapors at room temperature. The photoluminescence (PL) excitation and emission spectra were recorded on a Hitachi F-7000 spectrophotometer equipped with a 150 W xenon lamp as the excitation source. Prior to the measurements, some preparatory work was done. The as-synthesized sample of compound 1 was immersed into anhydrous methanol for 3 days and was refreshed three times with methanol every day; then, the wet sample was dried under vacuum at 40 °C for 12 h to yield activated materials. Solid samples of activated compound 1 were ground into powder and used for vapor sensing measurements. The details are as follows: The activated sample used as in situ time-dependent photoluminescence sensor for solvent vapors was prepared as follows: A ground sample (3 mg) was pressed into a firm sheet, then dropped the moderate anhydrous ethanol, which was attached to a thin quartz slide and placed into a cuvette, which can keep the film away from about 0.3 cm the bottom. It was then put under different solvent vapors, including nitrobenzene (NB), 2-nitrotoluene (2-NT), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 2-nitrophenol (2-NP), 3-nitrophenol (3-NP), 4-nitrophenol (4-NP), and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), as well as N,N-dimethylformamide, acetone, acetonitrile, methanol, ethanol, dioxane, i-propanol, phenylmethanol, and water. Subsequently, the sample tube was taken out and quickly sealed, and then the emission spectra were recorded. The quenching efficiency is defined by (I 0–I)/I 0 × 100%, where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities of the sensor before and after the addition of nitroaromatics, respectively. The solid-state emission spectra of the firm sheet sample was recorded as an initial standard; then, 0.3 mL or 10 mg of detectors was carefully added into the cuvette. The volume of the cuvette used was 2 cm3 with a length and width of 1 cm and a height of 2 cm.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Sensing Methodology

The luminescent properties were examined in the solid state, in organic solvent suspensions, and vapors at room temperature. The photoluminescence (PL) excitation and emission spectra were recorded on a Hitachi F-7000 spectrophotometer equipped with a 150 W xenon lamp as the excitation source. Prior to the measurements, some preparatory work was done. The as-synthesized sample of compound 1 was immersed into anhydrous methanol for 3 days and was refreshed three times with methanol every day; then, the wet sample was dried under vacuum at 40 °C for 12 h to yield activated materials. Solid samples of activated compound 1 were ground into powder and used for vapor sensing measurements. The details are as follows: The activated sample used as in situ time-dependent photoluminescence sensor for solvent vapors was prepared as follows: A ground sample (3 mg) was pressed into a firm sheet, then dropped the moderate anhydrous ethanol, which was attached to a thin quartz slide and placed into a cuvette, which can keep the film away from about 0.3 cm the bottom. It was then put under different solvent vapors, including nitrobenzene (NB), 2-nitrotoluene (2-NT), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 2-nitrophenol (2-NP), 3-nitrophenol (3-NP), 4-nitrophenol (4-NP), and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP), as well as N,N-dimethylformamide, acetone, acetonitrile, methanol, ethanol, dioxane, i-propanol, phenylmethanol, and water. Subsequently, the sample tube was taken out and quickly sealed, and then the emission spectra were recorded. The quenching efficiency is defined by (I 0-I)/I 0 × 100%, where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensities of the sensor before and after the addition of nitroaromatics, respectively. The solid-state emission spectra of the firm sheet sample was recorded as an initial standard; then, 0.3 mL or 10 mg of detectors was carefully added into the cuvette. The volume of the cuvette used was 2 cm3 with a length and width of 1 cm and a height of 2 cm.

elements.content: The luminescent spectra of compound 2 treated by containing different heavy metal ions aqueous solutions were first studied (ClO4 –, SO4 2–, NO3 –, Br–, Cl–, I–, SCN–, Cr2O7 2–, CH3COO–, (OAc–), C2O4 2–, (OX2–), W12O40P3–, Mo12O40P3–, AsO3 2–/HAsO3 –, VO4 3–); the concentration of each ion is 1.0 × 10–3 M). The standard suspensions were prepared by adding grinding sample (2 mg) into metal ion aqueous solution with the same concentration (3 mL) and then treated by ultrasonication for 20 min.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray analysis revealed that compound 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system, Cmca space group, and features a three dimensional highly porous pillared-layer framework. The asymmetry unit contains one and a half Zn­(II) ions, one TNB, and a half of TPPE. As shown in a, the Zn1 atom is five-coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three TNB and one nitrogen atom from a TPPE ligand. The length of Zn–N is 2.011(10) Å. Each TNB links three Zn­(II) ions through its three carboxyl groups, and the linkage between Zn­(II) ions and TNB ligands leads to the formation of a honeycomb-like layer [Zn3(TNB)] n with the centrosymmetric units of three zinc nuclei (e). One TPPE molecule connects four Zn­(II) ions (d), and the [Zn3(TNB)] n layers are further pillared by the TPPE ligands to form a 3D neutral framework with the microporous channels (f). The opening size of the window is about 18.4 × 14.3 Å2 along the c axis (Figure S2). The void volume of compound 1 is high up to 72.7% of the crystal volume (22169.4 out of 30474.6 Å3 unit cell volumes) without the consideration of the solvent molecules, calculated by PLATON (dynamic radius of N2 molecule as probe size = 1.80 Å). Interestingly, although the structure has so large scale windows and channels, there is no occurrence of the interpenetrations in the framework. In addition, from the perspective of electronics, if the double sheets [Zn3(TNB)] n were symbolized as the wall, it is an electron-rich wall. Further, along with the inserting of the TTPE, the π-electron-rich pores and channels were formed; then, a framework with the expanding π systems was constructed.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structural Characterization of MOFs

Single crystal X-ray analysis revealed that compound 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system,  Cmca space group, and features a three dimensional highly porous pillared-layer framework. The asymmetry unit contains one and a half Zn(II) ions, one TNB, and a half of TPPE. As shown in a, the Zn1 atom is five-coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three TNB and one nitrogen atom from a TPPE ligand. The length of Zn-N is 2.011(10) Å. Each TNB links three Zn(II) ions through its three carboxyl groups, and the linkage between Zn(II) ions and TNB ligands leads to the formation of a honeycomb-like layer [Zn3(TNB)] n  with the centrosymmetric units of three zinc nuclei (e). One TPPE molecule connects four Zn(II) ions (d), and the [Zn3(TNB)] n  layers are further pillared by the TPPE ligands to form a 3D neutral framework with the microporous channels (f). The opening size of the window is about 18.4 × 14.3 Å2 along the c axis (Figure S2). The void volume of compound 1 is high up to 72.7% of the crystal volume (22169.4 out of 30474.6 Å3 unit cell volumes) without the consideration of the solvent molecules, calculated by PLATON (dynamic radius of N2 molecule as probe size = 1.80 Å). Interestingly, although the structure has so large scale windows and channels, there is no occurrence of the interpenetrations in the framework. In addition, from the perspective of electronics, if the double sheets [Zn3(TNB)] n  were symbolized as the wall, it is an electron-rich wall. Further, along with the inserting of the TTPE, the π-electron-rich pores and channels were formed; then, a framework with the expanding π systems was constructed.

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system, space group Cmcm. Totally, compound 2 is a 3D cluster-organic framework. As shown a,b, the cluster consists of seven zinc ions and nine SO4 2–. The distribution of Zn2 is symmetric about the center of Zn1, forming a quadrilateral unit, and Zn3 was connected by SO4 2– to generate the binuclear units (e). Further, the quadrilateral units and the binuclear units link each other in the zinc cluster chain (c). Each TPPE ligand coordinates four Zn­(II) through Zn–N bonds. The length of Zn–N is 2.083(11) and 2.132(12) Å. As a result, the zinc cluster chains are bridged by TPPE ligands to form the 3D network with 1D rhombus pores (d). The dimensions of pores are calculated to be 11.4 × 9.8 Å2 along the b axis.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic system, I2 space group, and compound 3 is also one 3D cluster-organic framework. The coordinate environment contains one binuclear zinc unit and one TPPE molecule. Zn1 is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from one formate ion and one water molecule, and three nitrogen atoms from different TPPE ligands (a). Zn2 ions have the same coordination formation as well as that of Zn1. Each TPPE molecule adopts μ3-bridging coordination modes to coordinate three Zn­(II) ions by three pyridine groups. The length of Zn–N is 2.129(6) and 2.186(5) Å. Zn1 and Zn2 ions were connected by ligands to form the 3D network, respectively. The 3D networks are further linked by one formate ion to generate the final double-layer noninterpenetrating framework (b). Three ClO4 – as counterions are located into the pore to balance the charge of the whole framework.
elements.clean_text: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic system, I2 space group, and compound 3 is also one 3D cluster-organic framework. The coordinate environment contains one binuclear zinc unit and one TPPE molecule. Zn1 is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from one formate ion and one water molecule, and three nitrogen atoms from different TPPE ligands (a). Zn2 ions have the same coordination formation as well as that of Zn1. Each TPPE molecule adopts μ3-bridging coordination modes to coordinate three Zn(II) ions by three pyridine groups. The length of Zn-N is 2.129(6) and 2.186(5) Å. Zn1 and Zn2 ions were connected by ligands to form the 3D network, respectively. The 3D networks are further linked by one formate ion to generate the final double-layer noninterpenetrating framework (b). Three ClO4 - as counterions are located into the pore to balance the charge of the whole framework.

elements.content: The synthesis of three MOFs was systematically investigated. As a whole, the assembly of ligands and zinc ions was affected by solvent and acidity. Especially, the pH value plays a pivotal role in the formation of high quality crystals. As for 1, the crystals were obtained in DMA solution without acidic agents; if acidic agents (such as HBF4, HCCOOH, or HNO3) were added, the crystals become more brittle. In contrast, the acid needs to be added to generate the pure crystals of compound 2 and 3.

elements.content: First, the chemical resistance of compound 1 was investigated. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured, and the results indicated that the sample can maintain the crystallinity and morphology integrity for at least 1 month in the air (Figure S4). Such kind of highly porous zinc–organic framework is rare. However, the amorphization occurred in aqueous solutions for 3 days. Compound 2 is stable in water solution for at least 2 days. In addition, compound 3 is sensitive to moisture.

elements.content: Subsequently, the photoluminescence spectra of compounds 1–3 and the free ligand in the solid state were measured. As shown in , the linker precursor TPPE and TNB exhibit the emission maxima at 480 and 460 nm, respectively. The TPA and TPE-dual integrated compound 1 shows a strong yellow-green emission centered at 475 nm. Due to that the emission band of TNB is close to that of TPPE, there is no inner-filter effect of fluorescence between TNB and TPPE. The fluorescence emission of compound 1 should be attributed to the immobilized TPPE and TNB linkers in a rigid framework.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent Properties

Subsequently, the photoluminescence spectra of compounds 1-3 and the free ligand in the solid state were measured. As shown in , the linker precursor TPPE and TNB exhibit the emission maxima at 480 and 460 nm, respectively. The TPA and TPE-dual integrated compound 1 shows a strong yellow-green emission centered at 475 nm. Due to that the emission band of TNB is close to that of TPPE, there is no inner-filter effect of fluorescence between TNB and TPPE. The fluorescence emission of compound 1 should be attributed to the immobilized TPPE and TNB linkers in a rigid framework.

elements.content: Fluorescent spectra of compound 1, TNB, and TPPE in the solid state at room temperature, and fluorescent spectra of compounds 2 and 3.
elements.clean_text: 4  Fluorescent spectra of compound 1, TNB, and TPPE in the solid state at room temperature, and fluorescent spectra of compounds 2 and 3.

elements.content: The photoluminescent spectra of compounds 2 and 3 were also investigated in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in , the maximum emission peaks are at 497 and 510 nm for 2 and 3, respectively, under the excitation at 420 nm. On the one hand, the fluorescence peaks of these compounds are very close to that of the ligand; on the other hand, Zn­(II) ion belongs to the d10 configuration, which is difficult to oxidize or reduce. As a result, the luminescent behaviors of compounds 2–3 are probably attributable to the synthetic effects of intelligent intraligand and ligand-to-ligand charge transition. The enhancement of luminescence in d10 complexes may be attributed to ligand chelation to the metal center, which effectively increases the rigidity of the ligand and reduces the loss of energy by radiationless decay. Compared to the emission spectra of TPPE, compounds 2 and 3 exhibit the different levels of red shifts, and the emission behaviors for 2 and 3 not probably may be assigned to the diverse coordination microenvironment of Zn­(II) ions with TPPE ligands, which effectively increases the rigidity of the ligand and reduces the loss of energy by radiationless decay, but are attributed to the different arrangement formation in the crystal arrays.

elements.content: As a whole, compound 1 as a sensing system has the following several advantages: (i) the aggregation of tetraphenylethylene fluorophore units endows the strong fluorescence features in the frameworks; (ii) the high porosity and open channels of the structure provide the convenient passage for the diffusion of the target molecules; and (iii) the exceptional air stability of compound 1 favors the vapor-phase detection. The properties indicate that compound 1 can serve as a fluorescent probe for nitroaromatic explosives detection in vapor media.

The properties indicate that compound 1 can serve as a fluorescent probe for nitroaromatic explosives detection in vapor media.

elements.content: From the prospective of practice, it is more meaningful to achieve the vapor-phase detection of nitroaromatic explosives. For this, an in situ solid-state luminescent sensor device based on compound 1 as a probe was designed and fabricated (a). The time-dependent enhancing or quenching efficiency was carried out. We analyzed nitro-explosive sensing performances of porous thin film by keeping the films in a closed vial filled with nitro-explosive vapor and measuring their fluorescence intensities after certain time intervals.
elements.clean_text:
Vapor-Phase Detection of Nitroaromatic Explosives

From the prospective of practice, it is more meaningful to achieve the vapor-phase detection of nitroaromatic explosives. For this, an in situ solid-state luminescent sensor device based on compound 1 as a probe was designed and fabricated (a). The time-dependent enhancing or quenching efficiency was carried out. We analyzed nitro-explosive sensing performances of porous thin film by keeping the films in a closed vial filled with nitro-explosive vapor and measuring their fluorescence intensities after certain time intervals.

(b) Emission spectra of 1 upon exposure to the other nitro-explosives vapor at various time intervals at room temperature.

elements.content: As a whole, the film device shows the different response rates to the NACs; relatively selective responses for 2-NP, NB, and 2-NT were observed while quenching was remarkably lesser for all other analytes. The quenching of fluorescent emission with the different compounds examined in 5 min follows the order: 2-NT > 2-NP > NB > TNP > 2,4-DNT > 3-NP > 4-NP > 1,3-DNB (Figures S11–S18); evidently, the observations were in disagreement with the vapor pressures of the chosen NACs. For example, the vapor pressure of 2,4-DNT (1.44 × 10–6 mmHg) is much lower than that of 1,3-DNB (8.82 × 10–4 mmHg), but 2,4-DNT shows the faster quenching effect. As a matter of fact, the fluorescence quenching is the comprehensive outcome, such as orbit energy level of hosts and guests, diffusion, and the preparation of film. However, the film sensor of compound 1 displays the excellent ability for the trace of the vapor NACs. 2-NP and NB show a 70% and 66% quenching effect in 3 min of exposure time, respectively. The quenching efficiencies of the sample film against 2-NT, 2-NP, and NB after 300 s reach upward of at least 85%. Notably, the fluorescence quenching for TNP reaches a maximum level as long as 5 min with a nearly 35% quenching effect, although the vapor pressure of TNP is fairly low compared with that of the other NACs. These results show that the films are highly sensitive and selective toward sensing of NACs. Accordingly, we can conclude that the unique connotations of the metal–organic framework materials play a decisive role in detecting the NACs vapor. The framework consisting of the π-electron-rich pillars and the electron-rich layers creates the electron-rich microenvironment, which can strengthen the orbital overlap and the charge transfer effect between the electron-rich π system of the host matrix and the electron-deficient nitro-explosives. Moreover, such high porosity and the large channels of the framework supply the convenient space and passage for the diffusion of NAC gas molecules, which further enhance the host–guest contact and interaction. Besides, the TPPE linkers decorate the framework with the parallel arrangement, generating the π-stacking layer structure, which provides the most favorable place for electron transfer via the π–π interactions for the NACs adsorbed inside the channel. As a result, compound 1 can serve as a preferable detector toward the trace of NACs vapor. Due to eggregation-induced emission effect of TPE, as well as the high quantum yield and good photostability, TPE derivatives, such as tetrakis­(4-carboxyphenyl)­benzene and 1,1,2,2-tetrakis­(4-(pyridin-4-yl)­phenyl) ethane, have been selected as the prior ligands to construct electron-rich MOFs for the sensing of nitroaromatic compounds. To date, although many MOFs based on TPE derivatives exhibit the excellent detection features of nitroaromatic explosives in common or aqueous solution, this kind of MOFs for the vapor-phase detection is rare; to the best of our knowledge, this is the first reported MOF assembling from TPE derivatives, which was systematically investigated for detection of nitro-explosive vapor.

elements.content: Selectively is equally important to the sensitivity. In regard to this, exposure of the sensor to pure acetonitrile, dioxane, acetone, N,N-dimethylformamide, phenylmethanol, isopropanol, ethanol, and methanol did not result in a significant fluorescence quenching, not further getting rid of the solvent interference to the nitro-explosives sensing, but indicating the good selectivity of the sensor toward nitroaromatic explosives (Figure S19). Reusability is an important sensor parameter for the sensor applications. Thus, recycle experiments were implemented. 2-NT is selected as a mode. The emission spectrum of the film was recorded before and after exposure to the 2-NT vapor. In order to fully recover the fluorescence signal, the film was simply immersed in ethanol and washed for three times, then left to dry at room temperature for an additional 10 min. The experiments were repeated six times. As shown in , although the fluorescent intensity of the film was not fully recovered in each recovery cycle, because the film was hydrophobic, presumably ethanol could not penetrate through the pores of the film and the attached nitroaromatic molecules could not be remove absolutely; evidently, the intensity difference between the quenched and the recovered states enables the accurate sensing of 2-NT. Importantly, fluorescence intensity of the film does not markedly decrease than that of the original film, suggesting the good reusability of compound 1 thin film sensors.

elements.content: Given that high water stability of compound 2, this compound was selected as probe to detect the potential anions sensing properties in aqueous solutions. As shown in a, the luminescent measurements clearly illustrate that the different anions have the influence on the luminescent intensity of compound 2; remarkably, Cr2O7 2– has the largest quenching effect on the emission of compound 2 in aqueous solution (b, Figure S20). To understand the luminescent sensing mechanism of Cr2O7 2–, the titration experiment was carried out in water solution. The luminescent intensities of compound 2 gradually decreased with the increasing concentration of Cr2O7 2–; approximately 50% fluorescence quenching occurred only through the addition of 30 ppm (≈100 μM) of Cr2O7 2–, further achieving the complete quenching as low as 140 ppm (475 μM), which is far lower than that of the reported MOFs. It was probably attributed to the competitive absorption of light between Cr2O7 2– ions and the organic ligand; it caused to reduce the amount of light absorbed by the ligand, and resulted in reducing the efficiency of energy transfer from ligand to metal ions in the framework. Meanwhile, the selectivity was tested; the fluorescence intensity of the mixed solution before and after adding the Cr2O7 2– ions (each species with the same concentration is at 3 × 10–3 mol/L) was measured. The fluorescence emission was still remarkably quenched with the addition of Cr2O7 2–. It clearly confirmed that the other anions could not interfere with the Cr2O7 2– sensing (Figures S27–S29). In addition, the anions which are similar to dichromate, such as molybdate, phosphomolybdate, vanadate, arsenate/arsenite, and so on, were also selected as interfering ions to verify the selectivity. The experiments of the single component and hybrid components (the solution contains all anions) were carried out. In terms of a single component, the results show that 2 does not have a good response to these anions (Figures S21–S24). However, for hybrid components, compound 2 still shows the obvious quenched reactions even when the concentration of the other anions is 5-fold molar excess dichromate, suggesting the anions, including these ones that are similar to dichromate, could not interfere with the selective sensing of dichromate.
elements.clean_text:
Anion Sensing of Compound 2 

Given that high water stability of compound 2, this compound was selected as probe to detect the potential anions sensing properties in aqueous solutions. As shown in a, the luminescent measurements clearly illustrate that the different anions have the influence on the luminescent intensity of compound 2; remarkably, Cr2O7 2- has the largest quenching effect on the emission of compound 2 in aqueous solution (b, Figure S20). To understand the luminescent sensing mechanism of Cr2O7 2-, the titration experiment was carried out in water solution. The luminescent intensities of compound 2 gradually decreased with the increasing concentration of Cr2O7 2-; approximately 50% fluorescence quenching occurred only through the addition of 30 ppm (~100 μM) of Cr2O7 2-, further achieving the complete quenching as low as 140 ppm (475 μM), which is far lower than that of the reported MOFs. It was probably attributed to the competitive absorption of light between Cr2O7 2- ions and the organic ligand; it caused to reduce the amount of light absorbed by the ligand, and resulted in reducing the efficiency of energy transfer from ligand to metal ions in the framework. Meanwhile, the selectivity was tested; the fluorescence intensity of the mixed solution before and after adding the Cr2O7 2- ions (each species with the same concentration is at 3 × 10-3 mol/L) was measured. The fluorescence emission was still remarkably quenched with the addition of Cr2O7 2-. It clearly confirmed that the other anions could not interfere with the Cr2O7 2- sensing (Figures S27-S29). In addition, the anions which are similar to dichromate, such as molybdate, phosphomolybdate, vanadate, arsenate/arsenite, and so on, were also selected as interfering ions to verify the selectivity. The experiments of the single component and hybrid components (the solution contains all anions) were carried out. In terms of a single component, the results show that 2 does not have a good response to these anions (Figures S21-S24). However, for hybrid components, compound 2 still shows the obvious quenched reactions even when the concentration of the other anions is 5-fold molar excess dichromate, suggesting the anions, including these ones that are similar to dichromate, could not interfere with the selective sensing of dichromate.

elements.content: Quantitatively, this quenching effect was also calculated by the Stern–Volmer equation: I 0/I = 1 + K sv[M] (Figure S26). The K sv value for Cr2O7 2– is 1.09 × 104 M–1 obtained by the good line of I 0/I vs the concentration of Cr2O7 2– below 475 μM, displaying a strong quenching effect on the selected sample, and the theoretical conclusion indicates that the quenching process is with the coexistence of dynamic and static quenching processes. Meanwhile, the detection limit of compound 2 as a luminescent probe for detecting Cr2O7 2– is calculated based on the equation: DL = 3σ/K (1), σ = 100 × (S/I 0) (2) (K is the slope between the luminescence intensity vs the chromate concentration), where DL is the detection limit, S is the standard deviation of the luminescence intensity measurement, as determined by the baseline measurement of blank samples, and I 0 is the measured luminescence intensity of the compound in deionized water (). The detection limit is as low as 26.98 ppb (S/N = 3), which can match the reported MOF, such as [Ag­(m3-abtz)]·(NO3)·(0.125H2O) (9.98 ppb), which has one of the lowest values of chromium detection as shown in Table S1, and is significantly lower than the maximum contamination standard of Cr­(VI) in drinking water of 100 ppb defined by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). These results indicate compound 2 can serve as an efficient sensing platform for Cr2O7 2– targets.

Meanwhile, the detection limit of compound 2 as a luminescent probe for detecting Cr2O7 2- is calculated based on the equation: DL = 3σ/K (1), σ = 100 × (S/I 0) (2) (K is the slope between the luminescence intensity vs the chromate concentration), where DL is the detection limit, S is the standard deviation of the luminescence intensity measurement, as determined by the baseline measurement of blank samples, and I 0 is the measured luminescence intensity of the compound in deionized water (). The detection limit is as low as 26.98 ppb (S/N = 3), which can match the reported MOF, such as [Ag(m3-abtz)]⋅(NO3)⋅(0.125H2O) (9.98 ppb), which has one of the lowest values of chromium detection as shown in Table S1, and is significantly lower than the maximum contamination standard of Cr(VI) in drinking water of 100 ppb defined by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). These results indicate compound 2 can serve as an efficient sensing platform for Cr2O7 2- targets.

elements.content: In summary, three luminescent MOFs (1–3) have been successfully synthesized with π-electron-rich 1,1,2,2-tetrakis­(4-(pyridin-4-yl)­phenyl)­ethane (TPPE). Compound 1 features the highly porous pillared-layer framework with secondary H3NTB ligand. Interestingly, due to the convenient porous passage and electron-rich surface, the film of MOF as sensor exhibits the fast detection for nitrobenzene compounds with a response time of less than 3 min as well as good recyclability. Compound 2 shows the clear “turn-off” quenching responses for Cr2O7 2– in aqueous phase with high selectivity and sensitivity, and the detection limit is as low as 26.98 ppb, which is much lower than the maximum contamination standard of Cr­(VI) in drinking water of 100 ppb defined by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). The combination strategy of the luminescent functional ligands opens up brand new insight into sensitive and selective vapor-phase detection of nitroaromatic explosives and other targets.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, three luminescent MOFs (1-3) have been successfully synthesized with π-electron-rich 1,1,2,2-tetrakis(4-(pyridin-4-yl)phenyl)ethane (TPPE). Compound 1 features the highly porous pillared-layer framework with secondary H3NTB ligand. Interestingly, due to the convenient porous passage and electron-rich surface, the film of MOF as sensor exhibits the fast detection for nitrobenzene compounds with a response time of less than 3 min as well as good recyclability. Compound 2 shows the clear "turn-off" quenching responses for Cr2O7 2- in aqueous phase with high selectivity and sensitivity, and the detection limit is as low as 26.98 ppb, which is much lower than the maximum contamination standard of Cr(VI) in drinking water of 100 ppb defined by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). The combination strategy of the luminescent functional ligands opens up brand new insight into sensitive and selective vapor-phase detection of nitroaromatic explosives and other targets.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.056 g, 0.20 mmol), H3TNB (0.015 g, 0.042 mmol), and TPPE (0.010 g, 0.014 mmol) was added in a 25 mL glass vial; subsequently, 5 mL of dimethylacetamide (DMA) solvent was added to the solids. The vial was heated in a programmable oven at 373 K for 24 h, and a light yellow-green crystalline solid was obtained. The obtained yield: 81.4% (based on TPPE). Anal. Calcd for C81H74­N8O15Zn3: C, 58.55; H, 4.46; N, 6.75; Found: C, 59.66; H, 4.48; N, 6.24%.

Synthesis of Compound <bold>2</bold>

ZnSO4·7H2O (0.056 g, 0.20 mmol) and TPPE (0.010 g, 0.014 mmol) were mixed in a 25 mL glass vial; subsequently, 9 mL of solvent (DMF/i-PrOH/DMSO, 6:2:1 mL) was added, and another two drops of HBF4 were added by eyedropper. Then, the vial was heated in a programmable oven at 393 K for 96 h and cooled naturally. Further, the vials stayed still for 2 months, and a light yellow-green crystalline solid was obtained. The obtained yield: 10.2% (based on TPPE). Anal. Calcd for C92H75­N9O34­S7Zn7: C, 44.10; H, 2.92; N, 4.91; Found: C, 45.02; H, 2.98; N, 4.34%.

Synthesis of Compound <bold>3</bold>

cln_elements.content: Single crystal X-ray analysis revealed that compound 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system, Cmca space group, and features a three dimensional highly porous pillared-layer framework. The asymmetry unit contains one and a half Zn­(II) ions, one TNB, and a half of TPPE. As shown in a, the Zn1 atom is five-coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three TNB and one nitrogen atom from a TPPE ligand. The length of Zn–N is 2.011(10) Å. Each TNB links three Zn­(II) ions through its three carboxyl groups, and the linkage between Zn­(II) ions and TNB ligands leads to the formation of a honeycomb-like layer [Zn3(TNB)] n with the centrosymmetric units of three zinc nuclei (e). One TPPE molecule connects four Zn­(II) ions (d), and the [Zn3(TNB)] n layers are further pillared by the TPPE ligands to form a 3D neutral framework with the microporous channels (f). The opening size of the window is about 18.4 × 14.3 Å2 along the c axis (Figure S2). The void volume of compound 1 is high up to 72.7% of the crystal volume (22169.4 out of 30474.6 Å3 unit cell volumes) without the consideration of the solvent molecules, calculated by PLATON (dynamic radius of N2 molecule as probe size = 1.80 Å). Interestingly, although the structure has so large scale windows and channels, there is no occurrence of the interpenetrations in the framework. In addition, from the perspective of electronics, if the double sheets [Zn3(TNB)] n were symbolized as the wall, it is an electron-rich wall. Further, along with the inserting of the TTPE, the π-electron-rich pores and channels were formed; then, a framework with the expanding π systems was constructed.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structural Characterization of MOFs

Single crystal X-ray analysis revealed that compound 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system,  Cmca space group, and features a three dimensional highly porous pillared-layer framework. The asymmetry unit contains one and a half Zn(II) ions, one TNB, and a half of TPPE. As shown in a, the Zn1 atom is five-coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three TNB and one nitrogen atom from a TPPE ligand. The length of Zn-N is 2.011(10) Å. Each TNB links three Zn(II) ions through its three carboxyl groups, and the linkage between Zn(II) ions and TNB ligands leads to the formation of a honeycomb-like layer [Zn3(TNB)] n  with the centrosymmetric units of three zinc nuclei (e). One TPPE molecule connects four Zn(II) ions (d), and the [Zn3(TNB)] n  layers are further pillared by the TPPE ligands to form a 3D neutral framework with the microporous channels (f). The opening size of the window is about 18.4 × 14.3 Å2 along the c axis (Figure S2). The void volume of compound 1 is high up to 72.7% of the crystal volume (22169.4 out of 30474.6 Å3 unit cell volumes) without the consideration of the solvent molecules, calculated by PLATON (dynamic radius of N2 molecule as probe size = 1.80 Å). Interestingly, although the structure has so large scale windows and channels, there is no occurrence of the interpenetrations in the framework. In addition, from the perspective of electronics, if the double sheets [Zn3(TNB)] n  were symbolized as the wall, it is an electron-rich wall. Further, along with the inserting of the TTPE, the π-electron-rich pores and channels were formed; then, a framework with the expanding π systems was constructed.
